metadata.case_name: Bhatnagars & Co. Private Ltd. v. Union of India
metadata.case_number: Petitions Nos. 377 of 1955 and 42, 46, 164 and 423 of 1956

facts.text: Petitioner obtained a licence for the import of soda ash only worth about Rs. 50,00,000 during the free licensing period in 1952.
In pursuance of this licence, consignments of soda ash to the extent of 100 tons, 200 tons and 20 tons respectively were received at Bombay.
Customs Authorities received information that petitioner's capital did not exceed Rs. 15,000 and that he was trafficking in these licences.
Investigation made, matter left to Special Police Establishment; documents seized from petitioner's office and from Messrs N. Jivanlal Co. at Bombay.
Investigation confirmed complaint of trafficking; Messrs. N. Jivanlal Co. had free hand in dealing with licences; petitioner received commission for imports allowed in name of Bhatnagars Co.
In regard to consignments of 100 tons and 20 tons, imported by Messrs N. Jivanlal Co. who held no licence; consignments seized by Collector of Customs.
Offices raided: petitioner's on November 7, 1952; N. Jivanlal Co. on February 6, 1953.
Goods arrived in Bombay in March and April 1953; confiscated by Collector of Customs in May and June 1953.
Documents including licences seized were subsequently returned to petitioner.
Appeal to Central Board of Revenue dismissed.
Revision to Central Government dismissed on September 22, 1955.
On March 31, 1956, Collector of Customs ordered goods to be auctioned; interim stay obtained but vacated.
Previous petition No. 571 of 1954 heard on March 24, 1955; Solicitor-General gave undertaking that goods not to be sold for one month after communication of Central Government's order.
Press Note dated February 3, 1955 and Public Notice No. 25-ITC PN 56 dated June 30, 1956 on canalisation of soda ash import through importer-stockists.
Order dated May 3, 1954 by Controller of Imports and Exports: no licence or customs clearance permit granted upto July 1953; re-validation of licences not allowed.
Licences granted to petitioner alive for one year from February 13, 1952.

legal_issues.text: Whether respondents acted in contempt of court by not disposing of revisional petition within time allegedly undertaken.
Whether policy in Press Note dated February 3, 1955 and Public Notice dated June 30, 1956 creates monopoly violating fundamental right to trade.
Whether orders of confiscation and refusal to revalidate licences are illegal, entitling petitioner to revalidation.
Whether Imports and Exports (Control) Act, 1947 applies to soda ash import requiring licence.
Whether section 3 of Imports and Exports (Control) Act, 1947 is ultra vires as delegated legislation.
Whether finding of licence trafficking based on no legal evidence.

petitioner_arguments.text: Union of India and respondents in contempt for not disposing revisional petition within one month as per Solicitor-General's undertaking.
Policy statements in Press Note and Public Notice create monopoly violating right to carry on trade.
Confiscation illegal; licences should be revalidated as period expired due to illegal seizure.
Imports and Exports (Control) Act, 1947 does not apply to soda ash as r.84(2) Defence of India Rules omitted.
Section 3 of Act is delegated legislation without policy or guidance.
Finding of trafficking based on no legal evidence; petitioner obtained licences bona fide.

respondent_arguments.text: No undertaking given for disposal of revisional petition within specified time; order clear on one month stay post-communication.
Policy flexible for national interests; no monopoly created, canalisation to prevent malpractices.
Petitioner may have remedy by suit for damages, but not under Art.32; findings on trafficking by competent authorities under Sea Customs Act.

court_reasoning.text: No contempt; Solicitor-General's undertaking only for not selling goods for one month after communication of revisional order; no undertaking on disposal time.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Order plain and unambiguous; no scope for misunderstanding.

court_reasoning.text: Import/export policy flexible based on country's needs, foreign exchange, national industries; canalisation through stockists to stabilise prices and supply, not monopoly.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Petitioner not established importer; government duty to regulate malpractices.

court_reasoning.text: No jurisdiction under Art.32 to direct revalidation or challenge factual findings on trafficking; remedy if any by suit for damages.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Grievance against conclusions of fact by competent authorities.

court_reasoning.text: S.3(1)(a) applies to import of goods of specified description like soda ash; disjunctive reading; no need to re-enact r.84(2) Defence Rules.
Act continues powers from Defence of India Act; preamble and history show policy of maintaining essential supplies; covered by Harishankar Bagla.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Clear policy in preamble and predecessor Act.

court_reasoning.text: Legal evidence exists: poor capital, conduct, role of N. Jivanlal, false allegations; concurrent findings by authorities.

holdings.text: No relief under Art.32 for revalidation or against confiscation.
Imports and Exports (Control) Act, 1947 s.3 applies to soda ash import.
Finding of trafficking supported by legal evidence; not challengeable in writ.

precedents_cited.case_name: Harishankar Bagla v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Rejects challenge to delegated legislation in control Acts; policy in preamble sufficient guidance.

precedents_cited.case_name: Pannalal Binjraj v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: History of earlier Acts considered for underlying policy.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Jurisdiction invoked for writs enforcing fundamental rights; no jurisdiction for factual disputes.

statutes_cited.name: Sea Customs Act, 1878
statutes_cited.relevance: Goods deemed prohibited/restricted; provisions apply to confiscated goods.

statutes_cited.name: Imports and Exports (Control) Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Power to prohibit/restrict imports; applies to soda ash; not ultra vires.

outcome.summary: All five petitions dismissed; grievances against confiscation, seizure, policy, contempt, revalidation held misconceived; no jurisdiction under Art.32 for relief claimed.

key_quotes.text: The petitions show obvious traces of unskilled draftsmanship. They are extremely diffused and in many places incoherent.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: It would, therefore, be idle to suggest that there should be unfettered and unrestricted freedom of export and import.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects absolute right to trade in imports.

key_quotes.text: The essential legislative function consists in the determination or choice of the legislative policy and of formally enacting that policy into a binding rule of conduct.
key_quotes.speaker: court
